Graphical abstract Since the sluggish oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER) hinders the practical application of Li-O2 batteries, low cost and efficient bifunctional cathode catalysts are highly desired. LaFeO3 has attracted great interest as a promising electrocatalyst due to the abundance, low cost and non-toxity of Fe. But LaFeO3 bulk is almost inactive. Herein, we have developed a facile novel soft-template route to successfully prepare oxygen vacancies-enriched LaFeO3-x nanosheets which show a largely enhanced electrocatalytic activity on both ORR and OER. The electronic structure, bonding and coordination environment of O, Fe and La atoms have been comprehensively analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Li-O2 battery with LaFeO3-x nanosheets as catalysts show a high specific capacity, low overpotential and long cycle stability owing to the synergy of oxygen defect, Fe valence modulation and 2D nanosheets engineering. DFT calculation further reveals that oxygen adsorption will more likely occur on vacancy sites. In addition, the overpotential can be further lowered to about 0.6 V by LiI making the Li-O2 battery with the catalysis of LaFeO3-x more practical. This study presents some insights into designing the efficient electrocatalysts for Li-O2 battery through an integration of defect engineering, 2D nanosheets architecture and metal valence modulation. Keywords Li-O2 battery Electrocatalyst Oxygen vacancy Nanosheet Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction The application of the Li-O2 batteries has attracted great interest as a promising energy storage system has the merit of ultrahigh energy density [1–6]. But scientists still face the challenges of the poor cyclability, inferior rate capability, high overpotential and low energy efficiency. The insoluble discharged product (Li2O2) from the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR: 2Li+ + O2 + 2e− → Li2O2) aggregates on the cathode surface and gradually blocks the pathways of oxygen and electron, which leads to the electrochemical performance degradation [7–9]. Several strategies such as nanostructured catalysts design, electrolyte mediation and product regulation have been extensively applied [10–12]. Among these modification strategies, the design and exploration of the bifunctional cathode catalysts are highly desired for promoting both ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [13–15]. Noble metal compounds [16], transition metal nitrides and oxides [17], and carbon materials [18,19] have been extensively reported as catalysts for Li-O2 batteries. Perovskite oxides catalysts have been applied in solid oxide fuel cells and different metal-air batteries and show great performance [20–24]. Shao et al. reported that the σ*-orbital (eg) occupation and the extent of B-site transition-metal-oxygen covalency could be used to predict the performance of the perovskite catalysts [25]. And the intrinsic OER activity exhibited a volcano-shaped dependence on the occupancy of the 3d electron with an eg symmetry of surface transition metal cations in an oxide [26]. Recently, Wei et al. combined experiment results and calculation to support that eg occupancy can be used to predict the activity of perovskite nanomaterials [27]. Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity of perovskite oxides can be improved by doping with foreign elements [28,29], compositing with carbon materials [30] or by introducing appropriate vacancies [31–34]. LaFeO3 arouses a particular interest because of the abundance, low cost and non-toxicity of Fe but its electrocatalytic activity is very poor. How to activate LaFeO3 to get the high catalytic activity is highly desired. Zhang et al. improved the catalytic activity of LaFeO3 through forming 3D ordered microporous structures [35]. Shao et al. enhanced the electrocatalytic activity of ORR and OER in alkaline solution by tuning cation deficiency in LaFeO3 [36]. Recently, 2D nanosheets have attracted much interest due to their particular physical or chemical properties [37–39]. In this work, we have developed a novel and easy method to successfully prepare oxygen vacancy-enriched LaFeO3-x nanosheets (LaFeO3-x NS) by using GO and melamine as soft templates, which demonstrates a significant enhancement of electro activity for both OER and ORR reaction. And then the application of the Li-O2 battery also should great improvement. The electronic structure has been characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Raman and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy are also tested to support the result. Using oxygen vacancy-enriched LaFeO3-x NS to catalyse Li-O2 battery gets a great advance in enhancing specific capacity, reducing overpotential and increasing cycle stability than bulk LaFeO3 or oxygen vacancy-free LaFeO3 nanosheets (LaFeO3 NS) because the synergistic effects of the structured nanosheets, the O atoms defect of the lattice on the surface and the valence modulation of Fe. DFT calculation further shows that the vacancy sites can obtain lower adsorption energy of oxygen (ΔEo) so as to enhance the catalytic activity of LaFeO3-x NS so that absorption of oxygen will be likely to occur on vacancy site or near vacancy. The proposed strategy to prepare oxygen vacancies–rich LaFeO3-x nanosheets may also be applied to some other oxides. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Synthesis of the samples LaFeO3 NS & LaFeO3-x NS: 1 mmol of stoichiometric amounts of AR-grade lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O) and ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O) were dissolved in 15 ml of deionized water marked as solution A. Next, 10 ml of 10 mg/ml rGO and 1 g melamine were added to solution A. After vigorous stirring the solution for 12 h at room temperature for making sure the melamine and rGO are uniformity scattered, the solution was first quick-frozen by liquid nitrogen and then dried for 72 h in vacuum-freezing dryer. The obtained precursors were milled then annealed at 700 °C in Ar atmosphere for 4 h with a rate 2 °C/min to obtain ultrathin oxygen vacancy-enriched LaFeO3-x NS. To obtain the vacancy-free LaFeO3 NS, the same precursors was annealed in the same temperature process with air. Bulk LaFeO3 : Bulk LaFeO3 was prepared through a sol–gel method. 1 mmol of stoichiometric amounts of AR-grade lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O) and 2 mmol citric acids (CA,) were dissolved in 10 ml of deionized water. After stirred at room temperature for 1 h when the solution become transparent and homogeneous, the solution was aged at 80 °C for 12 h and then dried at 150 °C for 24 h to make sure that the water volatilized, and then this gel annealed at 700 °C for 4 h to obtain LaFeO3 samples. 2.2 Structure characterization of the samples Powder x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on Smartlab, a 9 kW-Rolling-Target powder diffractometer, (Rigaku, Cu Kα radiation λ = 0.154 nm) and the extent of 2θ is 20 to 80°. With a monochromatic X-ray source (E(Al Kα) = 1486.6 eV) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on Thermo escalab 250Xi to help us identify the atoms on the materials’ surface and the constitution of the molecular bond near the surface. In order to normalizing all the spectra, 284.6 eV as the line position of adventitious carbon was used. Soft XAS measurements were tested at Russian-German Beamline of the Synchrotron Bessy II, Berlin, Germany. At room temperature under ultrahigh vacuum (10−9 Torr), we tested both the total electron yield (TEY) and fluorescence yield (TFY) modes. Respectively, the TEY mode was used assess the sum of emitted electrons and the energy dispersive Bruker XFlash® fluorescence detector was applied in FY mode. Raman spectra were obtained from the RENISHEW inVia confocal Raman microscope with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm. Using a scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM SU8010 HITACHI) and transmission electron microscope (TEM FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN, acceleration voltage, 200 kV), the shapes and structures of the catalysts and cathodes no matter in charge or discharge states were obtained. The acceleration voltage of FE-SEM was below 5 kV, 10 uA with the work distance of 8 mm. The ICP-MS was carried out on Agilent 7500ce. 8 mg samples were first dissolved in nitric acid to ensure the volume to 25 ml and then attenuate 50 times for testing. Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) images were collected on Bruker Dimension Icon. Differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) was carried out on i-DEMS 100 (Linglu Instruments (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.). UV/vis for cathode carried out on Anglent Carry 60 with double electrode quartz cell. The solvent to detect Li2O2 is fresh H2SO4/TiOSO4 mixture. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a Micromeritcs ASAP-2020 analyzer. 2.3 Fabrication of oxygen cathode and electrochemical measurements A specially designed coin-cell with 28 holes was used to measure the electrochemical catalytic performances when they were applied toLi-O2 batteries. The constitution of the cell includes lithium foil anode and a porous air electrode separated by glass filter separator (Whatsman) and electrolyte (1.0 M LITFSI dissolved in dry TEGDME). The cathode materials were mixed following the rate with N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) to prepare catalyst slurry. The ration of catalyst, super P carbon and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) was 4:4:2. Then, carbon paper current collector was covered by the mixture to consist the porous air electrode, before testing, the electrode was kept at 120 °C under vacuum for 12 h to make sure it was dried. Limiting the concentrations of water and oxygen less than 0.1 ppm in an argon-filled glove box (Etelux, LAB2000) then the coin cells were assembled. The galvanostatic discharge and recharge process of the batteries with the extent of voltage between 2.0 ~ 4.5 V (vs Lithium) ware tested in LAND(Wuhan) CT2001A battery testing system at room temperature. Limiting the capacity to 1000 mAh·g−1 the cut off cycling test was completed at a current density of 100 mA·g−1. The EIS (Electrochemical impedance spectra) measurements of the pristine cells were carried out using a Princeton PMC-2000 electrochemical station. LSV testing was carried out on a Princeton PMC-2000 electrochemical station by using coin cells. The atmosphere in all the tests is pure O2 atmosphere. And the capacity and current density were assessed based on the total mass loaded on the cathode. 3 Result and discussion The preparation process of the LaFeO3-x NS is shown in Fig. 1 . GO and melamine are used as soft templates. The melamine particles with positive charges and Fe/La-GO layers with negative charges were assembled layer by layer. With the calcination temperature increased in Ar, the absorbed Fe3+ and La3+ were first hydrolyzed to form LaFeO3 extending along GO layers. Meanwhile, melamine gradually sublimated and GO layers were oxidized by NO3 –. Finally, LaFeO3 nanosheets with oxygen vacancies in the unit cell were obtained. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) shows that there are about 15% oxygen atoms off compared with LaFeO3 NS. For comparisons, oxygen vacancy-free LaFeO3 NS were prepared using a similar process but calcinated in air. Bulk LaFeO3 was prepared through a sol–gel method. Fig. 2 A shows the XRD patterns of LaFeO3 Bulk, LaFeO3 NS and vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS. The location and intensity of the peaks reflect the crystallographic structure of the materials. Three main peaks can be found at 2θ = 32.17°, 46.16°, and 57.41°, indicating the lattice planes of (1 2 1), (2 0 2) and (2 4 0), respectively. The peaks can be compared with the standard PDF card (JCPDS No. 34-1493) suggesting the existence of orthorhombic perovskite structure. Fig. 2B reflects the Raman shift of the two nanosheets. The bands at 284 and 429 cm−1 can be related to the one phonon scattering of La-O and Fe-O, while the other two bands at 628 and 1315 cm−1 were assigned to the two phonon scatterings of O2– [40,41]. No strong peaks can be seen from 1300 to 1600 cm−1 indicating that there are no rGO left on the LaFeO3-x NS. As shown in Fig. 2C, the thickness of LaFeO3-x NS is about 5 nm (from AFM image) with a large extension in two dimensions. Fig. 2D shows the TEM and HRTEM images of LaFeO3-x NS. The lattice spacing of 0.277 nm can be ascribed to the (1 2 1) plane of LaFeO3 [42]. Fig. S1 provides the EDS-mapping of LaFeO3-x NS, which shows a uniform distribution of La, Fe and O. In Fig. S2, some areas marked in the HRTEM image of LaFeO3-x NS reveal blurred, which might result from the distortion of the LaFeO3 atomic lattice due to the existence of vacancies [43]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (SXAS) were carried out to investigate the electronic structure, the bonding and coordination environment of O, Fe and La atoms in the two nanosheets: LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS. Fig. S3 shows the XPS spectrum of LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS. As shown in Fig. S3A, two satellite -marked peaks were showed at about 710.2 eV and 723.9 eV, which could be respectly attributed to Fe 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 [44]. The location of bonding energy indicates that the valence state of Fe in LaFeO3 is in the main form of Fe3+ [45]. The shift of O 1s peak to lower energy observed in Fig. S3B reflects the changes of the chemical state of oxygen atoms in LaFeO3-x NS. In order to further find out the effect of O-vacancies in the materials, SXAS was conducted. Fig. 2E and 2F show the comparison of O K-edge and Fe L-edge spectra for LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS, respectively. Since these curves from the excitation of O 1s electrons to the anti-bonding states which are arisen from the interacting of O 2p orbitals with orbitals on the coordinating atoms, they are very sensitive to the composition changes of the materials [46]. In Fig. 2E, Fe L3-edge spectra from LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS samples were analyzed along with that from Fe2O3. The peak located at 708.6 eV (peak A) due to the transition to non-bonding Fe 3d t2g orbitals, while the peak at 710.3 eV (B) arises from the transition to anti-bonding Fe 3d e∗ g states [47]. It is obvious that both of the two peaks shift to lower energy for the LaFeO3-x NS sample, indicating that the FeO6 octahedra is more distorted in LaFeO3-x NS due to the formation of oxygen vacancies [48]. The peaks from A to H at the O K-edge in Fig. 2F were caused by the interactions of the O 2p orbitals with Fe orbitals, to be exact, A can be assigned as the transitions to O 2p–Fe 3d t2g and B arises from the transitions to O 2p–Fe 3d e∗ g and the rest F&H is related to O 2p–Fe 4p/4s. As for LaFeO3-x NS, the OA peaks measured in both modes (TEY and TFY) are located at lower energy than those of LaFeO3 NS and Fe2O3, manifesting the changes in oxygen state [49,50]. All the changes observed from Fe and O can be attributed to the absence of oxygen atoms in the materials which further confirms the existence of O-vacancies in LaFeO3-x NS. Fig. 3 A reveals the initial capacity of the batteries based on the three kinds of LaFeO3. The battery-based on bulk LaFeO3 can only display an original capacity of 2829.8 mAh/g at the current density of 100 mA/g and the overpotential is 1.7 V which is much higher than others. In contrast, the other two LaFeO3 nanosheets based batteries exhibit an excellent initial capacity of over 10,000 mAh/g. As for LaFeO3-x NS, the capacity can almost reach 14,983 mAh/g. Even if the current density was increased to 400 mA/g, LaFeO3-x NS based battery can still display an initial capacity of 10,298 mAh/g, while LaFeO3 bulk based battery can only delivery a capacity of about 1000 mAh/g. (Fig. 3B) The initial capacity and rate capability results demonstrate that bulk LaFeO3 has a very poor OER and ORR performance. O-vacancy free LaFeO3 NS show better OER and ORR activity and O-vacancy-enriched LaFeO3-x NS shows the best. This is expected since the large surface area and surface oxygen vacancy not only promote Li+ or e− conductivity but also cause active sites to enhance the absorption ability of the product in discharge process, resulting in a largely enhanced OER and ORR activity [51,52]. In order to test the cycling performance of the three different catalysts, capacity cut-off experiments (1000 mAh/g) was conducted as shown in Fig. 3C, D. The first discharge/charge curve of the three different batteries can be observed in Fig. 3C. It should noted that the three samples exhibit a similar discharge voltage in the ORR process. We infer that it is because that at a low current density, the reaction mechanism on the three different LaFeO3 surface is similar. The determinant factor is the diffusion of oxygen on cathode, so when the capacity reaches 1000 mAh/g, it seems to share the similar discharge platform. Under this condition, the role of oxygen vacancies is to provide more active sites for the adsorption of discharge product which results in a larger capacity. When the current density increases, as shown in Fig. S4, the overpotential on discharge of LaFeO3-x-NS is much lower. It means under this condition vacancies can not only affect the adsorption of the discharge product but also affect the charge transfer so as to obtain a lower overpotential. For the OER process, similar to the results from Fig. 3A and 3B, LaFeO3 bulk shows the poorest OER performance and delivers a charge plateau at 4.4 V. It is obvious that the recharge capacity cannot reach 1000mAh/g even during the first cycle. In contrast, LaFeO3-x nanosheets based Li-O2 battery shows the lowest overpotential with a charge flat of 3.95 V. Fig. 3D shows the cycle performance of batteries. After 10 cycles, the discharge voltage of the battery using LaFeO3 bulk decreased sharply and stopped working after 14 cycles. However, the battery based on vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS displayed a largely improved cycle stability compared to others. Even after 60 cycles, a stable discharge voltage and capacity can still be attained. It is clear that the generation of oxygen vacancy in LaFeO3-x nanosheets not only improve the ORR and OER activity but also enhance the reversibility of the battery. From the above results, we infer that the vacancy of LaFeO3-x nanosheets mainly plays two main roles: it can enhance the conductivity of nanosheets as well as it can provide more active sites. According to the previous report, the existence of oxygen vacancy will slightly result in a reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+, which may increase the electronic conductivity [53]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation can provide direct evidence of the above conclusion on oxygen vacancies. DFT calculations are performed for oxygen adsorption on vacancy free LaFeO3 (1 1 0) and LaFeO3-x (1 1 0) lattice plane, which is a typical and mainly-exposed plane. During the calculation, some oxygen atoms have been removed from the surface and the sub-surface of LaFeO3 to simulate the LaFeO3-x. Fig. 4 provides the LaFeO3 crystal model with/without oxygen vacancies and the simulative adsorption sites. Five different adsorption sites were selected as shown in Fig. 4 so as to reflect the different surface conditions. Fig S5 shows the LaFeO3 crystal model without vacancy and the oxygen adsorption model. Table S1 provides the oxygen adsorption energy (ΔEo) on LaFeO3 surface and LaFeO3-x surface. Higher oxygen adsorption energy means strong absorbance of oxygen. From the table, we find that most of the active sites on LaFeO3-x surface exhibit a higher oxygen adsorption energy than that of LaFeO3 surface. It means, oxygen will preferentially tend to be adsorbed on oxygen vacancy site surface of LaFeO3-x. This result further confirms that oxygen vacancy can introduce more active sites so as to enhance the catalytic activity of LaFeO3-x NS. Rotating disk electrode (RDE) experiments were used to further evaluate the ORR & OER activities when the electrode was doped with different LaFeO3 catalysts. Through the comparison in different electrolyte systems, this RDE method can somewhat reflect the property of catalysts. All potentials of Fig. S6A and S6B refer to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Fig. S6A demonstrates the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of LaFeO3 bulk, LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS, the catalysts were loaded on GC electrode in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. And the revolving speed was 1600 rpm; scan rate was 10 mV/s. Obviously, the limiting current density of oxygen vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS catalyst is higher 3 mA/cm2 than and LaFeO3 which is a lot for electrocatalysts. What’s more, the onset potential also more positive than LaFeO3 bulk or the oxygen vacancy-free LaFeO3 NS, indicating a better ORR activity. Considering the effect of surface area, we have also compared the LSV curve after being normalized the surface area of catalysts. As shown in Fig. S7, the LSV curves exhibit a similar result to the above. After surface area normalizing, LaFeO3 bulk and LaFeO3 NS shows poor ORR performance while LaFeO3-x NS exhibit the best ORR activity (Fig. S7A), which confirms the effect of vacancy on ORR. The same conclusion can be obtained from the LSV curve in O2-saturated 1.0 M LITFSI/TEGDME solution in Fig. 5 A, since oxygen vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS also shows a lower overpotential and larger limiting current density. Fig. S8 also compares the performance after normalizing the surface area. The normalized result in 1.0 M LITFSI/TEGDME provides a more powerful evidence that oxygen vacancy plays a cricial role on ORR activity. After being normalized by surface area, LaFeO3-x NS also shows the highest current density of 70 mA/m2. As a bi-functional electrocatalysis, the OER activity of LaFeO3-x NS was also evaluated by recording LSV curves in 0.1 M KOH solution. Fig. S6B as well as Fig S7B show the LSV curves of LaFeO3 bulk, LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS. LaFeO3-x NS exhibits a greater catalytic current, implying the much better OER catalytic activity. Fig. 5B indicates the EIS results of LaFeO3 NS and LaFeO3-x NS based batteries. Compared the diameter of the semicircle, the oxygen vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS based battery has lower impedance. The semicircle can partly reflect the ionic and electronic conductivity because a higher conductivity can accelerate the charge transfer reactions at the same condition. In combination with Fig. S4, we conclude that the oxygen vacancy can affect charge/mess transfer so as to improve the ORR and OER activity [54]. In order to get a deep insight into the morphology changes of the LaFeO3-x nanosheets and discharge product during the charge/discharge process, SEM images were collected at different charge/discharge states as shown in Fig. 6 . The discharge products deposited along the surface of nanosheets when the first discharge process of 500 mAh/g finished. And lots of plate-like discharge products distributed randomly on the surface of LaFeO3-x NS while the capacity reached to 1000 mAh/g. After the following recharge process, the products almost fully disappeared. Similar phenomenon of Li2O2 can be proved in the XRD patterns in Fig. 6E. The peaks at 2θ = 32.78° and 34.83° of the cathodes after 10 h discharge assigned to the (2 0 0) and (2 0 1) lattice planes, respectively, of the lithium peroxide. While, after the recharge process, these peaks disappeared and no other obvious discharge products can be seen from the XRD patterns, demonstrating good reversibility [55,56]. However, SEM and XRD can only reflect the formation of Li2O2 qualitatively. In order to detect the ORR process quantificationally, we use differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) to detect the discharge process. As shown in Fig. S9, the relationship between oxygen consumption and Li2O2 formation can be clearly observed. Based on the oxygen consumption, the faradaic efficiency of Li2O2 is calculated to be 97%. This means, during the discharge process, oxygen almost totally reacted with lithium to form Li2O2. We also carried out the UV/vis measurement to further confirm the Li2O2 product on the discharged cathode (Fig. S10). As shown in Fig. S10, we can conclude that during the discharge process, Li2O2 indeed form on the cathode and the calculated yield of Li2O2 is about 78.9%. The measured yield is not 100% because UV/vis measurement is not an in-situ technique and some side reactions of Li2O2 are unavoidable when it was transferred from the battery for UV/vis measurement. From the analysis mentioned above, we find that oxygen vacancy-rich LaFeO3-x NS based Li-O2 battery shows largely enhanced electrochemical performances and reduced overpotential. To make it more practical and further reduce the overpotential, LiI was added into the electrolyte [57,58]. The addition of LiI will change the process of the OER but obtain a better performance. As shown in Fig. 7 A, all the batteries with or without LiI show similar discharge curves at about 2.6 V indicating the formation of the similar discharge products. However, during the first charge process, the battery with LiI shows a different charge flat at 3.2 V. In the second discharge process, the discharge flat of the LiI-free battery is the same as that of the first cycle. However, two flats at 3.0 V and 2.7 V appear for the battery with LiI due to the I−/I3 − redox, which can also be verified by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve (Fig. 7B). The reduction peak below 2.7 V in Fig. 7B can be attributed to the formation of Li2O2. The two oxidation peaks at 3.25 and 3.78 V are resulting from the reaction of I− → I3 − and I3 − → I2 [59,60]. Similar oxidation peaks can also be found in the LiI-addition cell without O2 as shown in Fig. 7C. During the charge process, I3 − and I2 can react with Li2O2 to form O2 [61,62]. At the second discharge process, I3 − was reduced to I− at about 3.0 V as a redox mediator. Fig. 8 illustrate the ORR and OER process with and without LiI. This redox reaction of I3 − and I− can help to decompose Li2O2 to obtain a lower overpotential and long cycle life as shown in Fig. 7D. LiI will further improve the property of the whole battery coordinating with LaFeO3-x NS. The reversibility of this system can be confirmed by XRD as shown in Fig S11. On the XRD pattern, after recharge process, no peaks belonging to Li2O2 can be found, which confirms the LiI contained Li-O2 battery system is reversible. 4 Conclusion Oxygen vacancy-enriched LaFeO3-x nanosheets with high ORR and OER activity have been achieved using rGO and melamine as soft templates. The Li-O2 battery based on LaFeO3-x NS shows an ultrahigh initial capacity, long-term cycle life and reduced overpotential. All of those improvements were caused by the synergistic effects of nanosheets architecture, the oxygen vacancies on the surface and Fe valence modulation. The O-vacancies on the surface or the architectured nanosheets can not only enlarge the surface absorption energy and provide more active sites but also promote Li+ or e− conductivity. DFT calculation also shows that the adsorption of O2 tends to occur on vacancy sites or near vacancy sites. Moreover, the absence of oxygen in the lattice results in the valence changes of Fe which further enhances the electrochemical performance. Different valence state of Fe can result in the increase of ionic and electronic conductivity. The overpotential can be further lowered to as low as about 0.6 V by LiI making the Li-O2 battery based on LaFeO3-x nanosheets more promising. This study also shows some ideals to designing bifunctional catalysts for Li-O2 battery by a synergy of oxygen defect, metal valence modulation and nanosheets engineering. coredata.dc:description: Since the sluggish oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER) hinders the practical application of Li-O2 batteries, low cost and efficient bifunctional cathode catalysts are highly desired. LaFeO3 has attracted great interest as a promising electrocatalyst due to the abundance, low cost and non-toxity of Fe. But LaFeO3 bulk is almost inactive. Herein, we have developed a facile novel soft-template route to successfully prepare oxygen vacancies-enriched LaFeO3-x nanosheets which show a largely enhanced electrocatalytic activity on both ORR and OER. The electronic structure, bonding and coordination environment of O, Fe and La atoms have been comprehensively analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman and soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Li-O2 battery with LaFeO3-x nanosheets as catalysts show a high specific capacity, low overpotential and long cycle stability owing to the synergy of oxygen defect, Fe valence modulation and 2D nanosheets engineering. DFT calculation further reveals that oxygen adsorption will more likely occur on vacancy sites. In addition, the overpotential can be further lowered to about 0.6 V by LiI making the Li-O2 battery with the catalysis of LaFeO3-x more practical. This study presents some insights into designing the efficient electrocatalysts for Li-O2 battery through an integration of defect engineering, 2D nanosheets architecture and metal valence modulation.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen defects-engineered LaFeO3-x nanosheets as efficient electrocatalysts for lithium-oxygen battery
